      Sparse Haptic Proxy: Touch Feedback in Virtual Environments Using a General Passive Prop
      
            
        
               
      • Lung-Pan Cheng, 
        • 
               
      • Eyal Ofek, 
        • 
               
      • Christian Holz, 
        • 
               
      • Hrvoje Benko, 
        • 
               
      • Andrew D. Wilson
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '17: Proceedings of the 2017 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2017, pp 37183728https://doi.org/10.1145/3025453.3025753
      
            
      
               		
               
      We propose a class of passive haptics that we call Sparse Haptic Proxy: a set of geometric
                  primitives that simulate touch feedback in elaborate virtual reality scenes. Unlike
                  previous passive haptics that replicate the virtual environment in physical ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 40
          • 
                                 
        • 1,091
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics
        
                                 
        Total Citations40
        
                                 
        Total Downloads1,091
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months343
        
                                 
        Last 6 weeks60
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 2
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Supplementary Material
        
                                 
        pn2491p.mp4
        
                                 
        pn2491-file3.mp4
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      We propose a class of passive haptics that we call Sparse Haptic Proxy: a set of geometric primitives that simulate touch feedback in elaborate  virtual reality scenes. Unlike previous passive haptics that replicate the  virtual environment in physical space, a Sparse Haptic Proxy simulates a scene's detailed geometry by redirecting the user's hand to a matching primitive of the proxy.
      We demonstrate our system with two  virtual scenes: a flight cockpit and a room quest game. While their scene geometries differ substantially, both use the same sparse haptic proxy to provide haptic feedback to the user during task completion.

      The Object Inside: Assessing 3D Examination with a Spherical Handheld Perspective-Corrected Display
      
            
        
               
      • Francois Berard, 
        • 
               
      • Thibault Louis
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '17: Proceedings of the 2017 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2017, pp 43964404https://doi.org/10.1145/3025453.3025806
      
            
      
               		
               
      Handheld Perspective Corrected Displays (HPCDs) can create the feeling of holding
                  a virtual 3D object. They offer a direct interaction that is isomorphic to the manipulation
                  of physical objects. This illusion depends on the ability to provide a natural ...

        pn2758-file3.mp4
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      Handheld Perspective Corrected Displays (HPCDs) can create the feeling of holding a  virtual 3D object. They offer a direct interaction that is isomorphic to the  manipulation of physical objects. This illusion depends on the ability to provide a natural visuomotor coupling.
      The task involved the inspection of complex  virtual 3D puzzles. Physical puzzles were also tested as references.

      Prospective motor control on tabletops: planning grasp for multitouch interaction
      
            
        
               
      • Halla B. Olafsdottir, 
        • 
               
      • Theophanis Tsandilas, 
        • 
               
      • Caroline Appert
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '14: Proceedings of the SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsApril 2014, pp 28932902https://doi.org/10.1145/2556288.2557029
      
            
      
               		
               
      Substantial amount of research in Psychology has studied how people manipulate objects
                  in the physical world. This work has unveiled that people show strong signs of prospective
                  motor planning, i.e., they choose initial grasps that avoid uncomfortable ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 9
          • 
                                 
        • 323
          •

        Supplementary Material
        
                                 
        pn0426-file3.mp4
        
                                 
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      Substantial amount of research in Psychology has studied how people  manipulate objects in the physical world.
      Interactive tabletops allow their users great flexibility in the  manipulation of  virtual objects but to our knowledge previous work has never examined whether prospective motor control takes place in this context.
      We systematically studied how users adapt their grasp when asked to translate and rotate  virtual objects on a multitouch tabletop.

      The Effect of Offset Correction and Cursor on Mid-Air Pointing in Real and Virtual
                     Environments
      
            
        
               
      • Sven Mayer, 
        • 
               
      • Valentin Schwind, 
        • 
               
      • Robin Schweigert, 
        • 
               
      • Niels Henze
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '18: Proceedings of the 2018 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsApril 2018, Paper No.: 653, pp 113https://doi.org/10.1145/3173574.3174227
      
            
      
               		
               
      Pointing at remote objects to direct others' attention is a fundamental human ability.
                  Previous work explored methods for remote pointing to select targets. Absolute pointing
                  techniques that cast a ray from the user to a target are affected by humans' ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 15
          • 
                                 
        • 389
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics
        
                                 
        Total Citations15
        
                                 
        Total Downloads389
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months161
        
                                 
        Last 6 weeks21
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 1
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Supplementary Material
        
                                 
        pn4903-file5.mp4
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      Previous work explored methods for remote pointing to  select targets. Absolute pointing techniques that cast a ray from the user to a target are affected by humans' limited pointing accuracy.
      In this paper, we investigate mid-air pointing in the real world and  virtual reality. Through a pointing study, we model the offsets to improve pointing accuracy and show that being in a  virtual environment affects how users point at targets.
      We further show that a cursor improves pointing accuracy but also increases the  selection time.

      Design and Evaluation of a Handheld-based 3D User Interface for Collaborative Object
                     Manipulation
      
            
        
               
      • Jernimo Gustavo Grandi, 
        • 
               
      • Henrique Galvan Debarba, 
        • 
               
      • Luciana Nedel, 
        • 
               
      • Anderson Maciel
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '17: Proceedings of the 2017 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2017, pp 58815891https://doi.org/10.1145/3025453.3025935
      
            
      
               		
               
      Object manipulation in 3D virtual environments demands a combined coordination of
                  rotations, translations and scales, as well as the camera control to change the user's
                  viewpoint. Then, for many manipulation tasks, it would be advantageous to share the
                  ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 11
          • 
                                 
        • 546
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics
        
                                 
        Total Citations11
        
                                 
        Total Downloads546
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months131
        
                                 
        Last 6 weeks21
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 1
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Supplementary Material
        
                                 
        pn3827.mp4
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      Object  manipulation in 3D  virtual environments demands a combined coordination of rotations, translations and scales, as well as the camera control to change the user's viewpoint. Then, for many  manipulation tasks, it would be advantageous to share the interaction complexity among team members.
      Our technique explores a smartphone -- the touchscreen and inertial sensors -- as input interface, enabling several users to collaboratively  manipulate the same  virtual object with their own devices.

      The Effect of Stereo Display Deficiencies on Virtual Hand Pointing
      
            
        
               
      • Mayra Donaji Barrera Machuca, 
        • 
               
      • Wolfgang Stuerzlinger
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '19: Proceedings of the 2019 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2019, Paper No.: 207, pp 114https://doi.org/10.1145/3290605.3300437
      
            
      
               		
               
      The limitations of stereo display systems affect depth perception, e.g., due to the
                  vergence-accommodation conflict or diplopia. We performed three studies to understand
                  how stereo display deficiencies impact 3D pointing for targets in front of a screen
                  ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 12
          • 
                                 
        • 259
          •

        paper207.mp4
        
                                 
        paper207p.mp4
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      Our first two experiments compare movements with and without a change in visual depth for  virtual respectively physical targets. Results indicate that  selecting targets along the depth axis is slower and has less throughput for  virtual targets, while physical pointing demonstrates the opposite result.

      RayCursor: A 3D Pointing Facilitation Technique based on Raycasting
      
            
        
               
      • Marc Baloup, 
        • 
               
      • Thomas Pietrzak, 
        • 
               
      • Gry Casiez
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '19: Proceedings of the 2019 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2019, Paper No.: 101, pp 112https://doi.org/10.1145/3290605.3300331
      
            
      
               		
               
      Raycasting is the most common target pointing technique in virtual reality environments.
                  However, performance on small and distant targets is impacted by the accuracy of the
                  pointing device and the user's motor skills. Current pointing facilitation ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 12
          • 
                                 
        • 700
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics
        
                                 
        Total Citations12
        
                                 
        Total Downloads700
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months506
        
                                 
        Last 6 weeks95
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 3
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Supplementary Material
        
                                 
        paper101p.mp4
        
                                 
        paper101vc.zip
        
                                 
        paper101.mp4
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      Raycasting is the most common target pointing technique in  virtual reality environments. However, performance on small and distant targets is impacted by the accuracy of the pointing device and the user's motor skills. Current pointing facilitation techniques are currently only applied in the context of the  virtual hand, i.e. for targets within reach. We propose enhancements to Raycasting: filtering the ray, and adding a controllable cursor on the ray to  select the nearest target.

      research-article
      
         
         
         
         
      Published By ACM
      
         
      
      
      
      
      
         
      
            
      Designing effective gaze mechanisms for virtual agents
      
            
        
               
      • Sean Andrist, 
        • 
               
      • Tomislav Pejsa, 
        • 
               
      • Bilge Mutlu, 
        • 
               
      • Michael Gleicher
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '12: Proceedings of the SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2012, pp 705714https://doi.org/10.1145/2207676.2207777
      
            
      
               		
               
      Virtual agents hold great promise in human-computer interaction with their ability
                  to afford embodied interaction using nonverbal human communicative cues. Gaze cues
                  are particularly important to achieve significant high-level outcomes such as improved
                  ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 31
          • 
                                 
        • 869
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics
        
                                 
        Total Citations31
        
                                 
        Total Downloads869
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months97
        
                                 
        Last 6 weeks22
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      Virtual agents hold great promise in human-computer interaction with their ability to afford embodied interaction using nonverbal human communicative cues.
      In a user study, we investigated how  manipulations in these variables might improve affiliation with the agent and learning.
      Our model and findings offer guidelines for the design of effective gaze behaviors for  virtual agents.

      TouchTools: leveraging familiarity and skill with physical tools to augment touch interaction
      
            
        
               
      • Chris Harrison, 
        • 
               
      • Robert Xiao, 
        • 
               
      • Julia Schwarz, 
        • 
               
      • Scott E. Hudson
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '14: Proceedings of the SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsApril 2014, pp 29132916https://doi.org/10.1145/2556288.2557012
      
            
      
               		
               
      The average person can skillfully manipulate a plethora of tools, from hammers to
                  tweezers. However, despite this remarkable dexterity, gestures on today's touch devices
                  are simplistic, relying primarily on the chording of fingers: one-finger pan, two-...
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 21
          • 
                                 
        • 623
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics
        
                                 
        Total Citations21
        
                                 
        Total Downloads623
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months42
        
                                 
        Last 6 weeks16
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 1
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Supplementary Material
        
                                 
        pn0343-file3.mp4
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      The average person can skillfully  manipulate a plethora of tools, from hammers to tweezers. However, despite this remarkable dexterity, gestures on today's touch devices are simplistic, relying primarily on the chording of fingers: one-finger pan, two-finger pinch, four-finger swipe and similar. We propose that touch gesture design be inspired by the  manipulation of physical tools from the real world.
      With only a few minutes of training on a proof-of-concept system, users were able to summon a variety of  virtual tools by replicating their corresponding real-world grasps.

      Haptic-Enabled Handheld Mobile Robots: Design and Analysis
      
            
        
               
      • Ayberk zgr, 
        • 
               
      • Wafa Johal, 
        • 
               
      • Francesco Mondada, 
        • 
               
      • Pierre Dillenbourg
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '17: Proceedings of the 2017 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2017, pp 24492461https://doi.org/10.1145/3025453.3025994
      
            
      
               		
               
      The Cellulo robots are small tangible robots that are designed to represent virtual
                  interactive point-like objects that reside on a plane within carefully designed learning
                  activities. In the context of these activities, our robots not only display ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 9
          • 
                                 
        • 497
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics

        Total Downloads497
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months90
        
                                 
        Last 6 weeks12
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      The Cellulo robots are small tangible robots that are designed to represent  virtual interactive point-like objects that reside on a plane within carefully designed learning activities.
      We show that our robot is usable in most of the tested tasks and extract perceptive and  manipulative guidelines for the design of haptic elements to be integrated in future learning activities.

      Interaction with magic lenses: real-world validation of a Fitts' Law model
      
            
        
               
      • Michael Rohs, 
        • 
               
      • Antti Oulasvirta, 
        • 
               
      • Tiia Suomalainen
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '11: Proceedings of the SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2011, pp 27252728https://doi.org/10.1145/1978942.1979343
      
            
      
               		
               
      Rohs and Oulasvirta (2008) proposed a two-component Fitts' law model for target acquisition
                  with magic lenses in mobile augmented reality (AR) with 1) a physical pointing phase,
                  in which the target can be directly observed on the background surface, and ...
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 20
          • 
                                 
        • 587
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics
        
                                 
        Total Citations20
        
                                 
        Total Downloads587
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months46
        
                                 
        Last 6 weeks10
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      Rohs and Oulasvirta (2008) proposed a two-component Fitts' law model for target acquisition with magic lenses in mobile augmented reality (AR) with 1) a physical pointing phase, in which the target can be directly observed on the background surface, and 2) a  virtual pointing phase, in which the target can only be observed through the device display.
      In the present outdoor study, subjects (N=12) did building- selection tasks in an urban area. The differences in task characteristics to the laboratory study are drastic: targets are three-dimensional and they vary in shape, size, z-distance, and visual context.

      Modeling Error Rates in Spatiotemporal Moving Target Selection
      
            
        
               
      • Jin Huang, 
        • 
               
      • Byungjoo Lee
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI EA '19: Extended Abstracts of the 2019 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2019, Paper No.: LBW2411, pp 16https://doi.org/10.1145/3290607.3313077
      
            
      
               		
               
      When we try to acquire a moving target such as hitting a virtual tennis in a computer
                  game, we must hit the target instantly when it flies over our hitting range. In other
                  words, we have to acquire the target in spatial and temporal domains ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 1
          • 
                                 
        • 137
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics
        
                                 
        Total Citations1
        
                                 
        Total Downloads137
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months109
        
                                 
        Last 6 weeks8
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      When we try to acquire a moving target such as hitting a  virtual tennis in a computer game, we must hit the target instantly when it flies over our hitting range.
      We call this type of task spatiotemporal moving target  selection, which we find is common yet less studied in HCI. This paper presents a tentative model for predicting the error rates in spatiotemporal moving target  selection.

      ForceRay: Extending Thumb Reach via Force Input Stabilizes Device Grip for Mobile Touch Input
      
            
        
               
      • Christian Corsten, 
        • 
               
      • Marcel Lahaye, 
        • 
               
      • Jan Borchers, 
        • 
               
      • Simon Voelker
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '19: Proceedings of the 2019 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2019, Paper No.: 212, pp 112https://doi.org/10.1145/3290605.3300442
      
            
      
               		
               
      Smartphones are used predominantly one-handed, using the thumb for input. Many smartphones,
                  however, have grown beyond 5". Users cannot tap everywhere on these screens without
                  destabilizing their grip. ForceRay (FR) lets users aim at an out-of-reach ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 5
          • 
                                 
        • 656
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics
        
                                 
        Total Citations5
        
                                 
        Total Downloads656
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months471
        
                                 
        Last 6 weeks77
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 5
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Supplementary Material
        
                                 
        pn4509vc.zip
        
                                 
        paper212p.mp4
        
                                 
        pn4509.mp4
        
                                 
        paper212.mp4
        
                                 
        paper212pvc.zip
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      ForceRay (FR) lets users aim at an out-of-reach target by applying a force touch at a comfortable thumb location, casting a  virtual ray towards the target.
      When reaching the target, quickly lifting the thumb  selects it. In a first study, FR was 195 ms slower and had a 3% higher  selection error than the best existing technique, BezelCursor (BC), but FR caused significantly less device movement than all other techniques, letting users maintain a steady grip and removing their concerns about device drops.

      Hybrid-Brailler: Combining Physical and Gestural Interaction for Mobile Braille Input and Editing
      
            
        
               
      • Daniel Trindade, 
        • 
               
      • Andr Rodrigues, 
        • 
               
      • Tiago Guerreiro, 
        • 
               
      • Hugo Nicolau
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '18: Proceedings of the 2018 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsApril 2018, Paper No.: 27, pp 112https://doi.org/10.1145/3173574.3173601
      
            
      
               		
               
      Braille input enables fast nonvisual entry speeds on mobile touchscreen devices. Yet,
                  the lack of tactile cues commonly results in typing errors, which are hard to correct.
                  We propose Hybrid-Brailler, an input solution that combines physical and ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      •

      Abstract
      Gestures are used in editing operations, such as caret movement, text  selection, and clipboard control, enhancing the overall text entry experience.
      Results show that Hybrid-Brailler supports fast entry rates as its  virtual counterpart, while significantly increasing input accuracy.

      DMove: Directional Motion-based Interaction for Augmented Reality Head-Mounted Displays
      
            
        
               
      • Wenge Xu, 
        • 
               
      • Hai-Ning Liang, 
        • 
               
      • Yuxuan Zhao, 
        • 
               
      • Difeng Yu, 
        • 
               
      • Diego Monteiro
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '19: Proceedings of the 2019 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2019, Paper No.: 444, pp 114https://doi.org/10.1145/3290605.3300674
      
            
      
               		
               
      We present DMove, directional motion-based interaction for Augmented Reality (AR)
                  Head-Mounted Displays (HMDs) that is both hands- and device-free. It uses directional
                  walk-ing as a way to interact with virtual objects. To use DMove, a user needs to
                  ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 4
          • 
                                 
        • 474
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics
        
                                 
        Total Citations4
        
                                 
        Total Downloads474
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months342
        
                                 
        Last 6 weeks42
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      It uses directional walk-ing as a way to interact with  virtual objects. To use DMove, a user needs to perform directional motions such as mov-ing one foot forward or backward.
      We then optimize its design and conduct a sec-ond study to compare DMove in task performance and user preferences (workload, motion sickness, user experience), with two approaches-Hand interaction (Meta 2-like) and Head+Hand interaction (HoloLens-like) for menu  selection tasks.

      COMPASS: Rotational Keyboard on Non-Touch Smartwatches
      
            
        
               
      • Xin Yi, 
        • 
               
      • Chun Yu, 
        • 
               
      • Weijie Xu, 
        • 
               
      • Xiaojun Bi, 
        • 
               
      • Yuanchun Shi
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '17: Proceedings of the 2017 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2017, pp 705715https://doi.org/10.1145/3025453.3025454
      
            
      
               		
               
      Entering text is very challenging on smartwatches, especially on non-touch smartwatches
                  where virtual keyboards are unavailable. In this paper, we designed and implemented
                  COMPASS, a non-touch bezel-based text entry technique. COMPASS positions multiple
                  ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 21
          • 
                                 
        • 1,534

        Supplementary Material
        
                                 
        p705-yi.mp4
        
                                 
        pn1002p.mp4
        
                                 
        pn1002-file3.mp4
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      Entering text is very challenging on smartwatches, especially on non-touch smartwatches where  virtual keyboards are unavailable.
      To enter text, a user rotates the bezel to  select keys with any nearby cursors. The design of COMPASS was justified by an iterative design process and user studies.

      Mouse, Tactile, and Tangible Input for 3D Manipulation
      
            
        
               
      • Lonni Besanon, 
        • 
               
      • Paul Issartel, 
        • 
               
      • Mehdi Ammi, 
        • 
               
      • Tobias Isenberg
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '17: Proceedings of the 2017 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2017, pp 47274740https://doi.org/10.1145/3025453.3025863
      
            
      
               		
               
      We evaluate the performance and usability of mouse-based, touch-based, and tangible
                  interaction for manipulating objects in a 3D virtual environment. This comparison
                  is a step toward a better understanding of the limitations and benefits of these ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 20
          •

      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      We evaluate the performance and usability of mouse-based, touch-based, and tangible interaction for  manipulating objects in a 3D  virtual environment.
      For this purpose we analyze participants' performance in 3D  manipulation using a docking task. We measured completion times, docking accuracy, as well as subjective criteria such as fatigue, workload, and preference.

      Handsaw: tangible exploration of volumetric data by direct cut-plane projection
      
            
        
               
      • Leonardo Bonanni, 
        • 
               
      • Jason Alonso, 
        • 
               
      • Neil Chao, 
        • 
               
      • Greg Vargas, 
        • 
               
      • Hiroshi Ishii
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '08: Proceedings of the SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsApril 2008, pp 251254https://doi.org/10.1145/1357054.1357098
      
            
      
               		
               
      Tangible User Interfaces are well-suited to handling three-dimensional data sets by
                  direct manipulation of real objects in space, but current interfaces can make it difficult
                  to look inside dense volumes of information. This paper presents the Handsaw, ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 7
          • 
                                 
        • 1,092
          •

        1357098.mp4
        
                                 
        index.html
        
                                 
        p251-slides.zip
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      Tangible User Interfaces are well-suited to handling three-dimensional data sets by direct  manipulation of real objects in space, but current interfaces can make it difficult to look inside dense volumes of information. This paper presents the Handsaw, a system that detects a  virtual cut-plane projected by an outstretched hand or laser-line directly on an object or space and reveals sectional data on an adjacent display.

      iGYM: A Wheelchair-Accessible Interactive Floor Projection System for Co-located Physical
                     Play
      
            
        
               
      • Roland Graf, 
        • 
               
      • Sun Young Park, 
        • 
               
      • Emma Shpiz, 
        • 
               
      • Hun Seok Kim
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI EA '19: Extended Abstracts of the 2019 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2019, Paper No.: LBW1615, pp 16https://doi.org/10.1145/3290607.3312792
      
            
      
               		
               
      Physical play opportunities for people with motor disabilities typically do not include
                  co-located play with peers without disabilities in traditional sport settings. In
                  this paper, we present a prototype of a wheelchair-accessible interactive floor ...

        lbw1615p.mp4
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      In this paper, we present a prototype of a wheelchair-accessible interactive floor projection system, iGYM, designed to enable people with motor disabilities to compete on par with, and in the same environment as, peers without disabilities. iGYM provides two key system features-peripersonal circle interaction and adjustable game mechanic (physics)-that enable individualized game calibration and wheelchair-accessible  manipulation of  virtual targets on the floor.

      Augmented Reality Views for Occluded Interaction
      
            
        
               
      • Klemen Lilija, 
        • 
               
      • Henning Pohl, 
        • 
               
      • Sebastian Boring, 
        • 
               
      • Kasper Hornbk
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '19: Proceedings of the 2019 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2019, Paper No.: 446, pp 112https://doi.org/10.1145/3290605.3300676
      
            
      
               		
               
      We rely on our sight when manipulating objects. When objects are occluded, manipulation
                  becomes difficult. Such occluded objects can be shown via augmented reality to re-enable
                  visual guidance. However, it is unclear how to do so to best support object ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 2
          • 
                                 
        • 530
          •

        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      We rely on our sight when  manipulating objects. When objects are occluded,  manipulation becomes difficult.
      The former enabled participants to observe the  manipulated object through the occluder, while the latter showed the 3D view of the  manipulated object offset from the object's real location.
      Our results suggest that alignment of  virtual objects with their real-world location is less important than an appropriate point-of-view and view stability.

      SIG: Spatiality of Augmented Reality User Interfaces
      
            
        
               
      • Alla Vovk, 
        • 
               
      • Danilo Gasques Rodrigues, 
        • 
               
      • Fridolin Wild, 
        • 
               
      • Nadir Weibel
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI EA '19: Extended Abstracts of the 2019 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2019, Paper No.: SIG02, pp 14https://doi.org/10.1145/3290607.3311756
      
            
      
               		
               
      Augmented reality and spatial information manipulation is being increasingly used
                  as part of environ- ment integrated form factors and wearable device such as head-mounted
                  displays. The integration of this exciting technology in many aspects of peoples'
                  ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 0
          • 
                                 
        • 208
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics
        
                                 
        Total Citations0
        
                                 
        Total Downloads208
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months150
        
                                 
        Last 6 weeks9
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      Augmented reality and spatial information  manipulation is being increasingly used as part of environ- ment integrated form factors and wearable device such as head-mounted displays. The integration of this exciting technology in many aspects of peoples' lives is transforming the way we understand computing, pushing the boundaries of Spatial Interfaces into  virtual but embedded environments.

      Remixed Reality: Manipulating Space and Time in Augmented Reality
      
            
        
               
      • David Lindlbauer, 
        • 
               
      • Andy D. Wilson
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '18: Proceedings of the 2018 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsApril 2018, Paper No.: 129, pp 113https://doi.org/10.1145/3173574.3173703
      
            
      
               		
               
      We present Remixed Reality, a novel form of mixed reality. In contrast to classical
                  mixed reality approaches where users see a direct view or video feed of their environment,
                  with Remixed Reality they see a live 3D reconstruction, gathered from multiple ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 14
          • 
                                 
        • 1,630
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics
        
                                 
        Total Citations14
        
                                 
        Total Downloads1,630
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months499
        
                                 
        Last 6 weeks75
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 2
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Supplementary Material
        
                                 
        pn1866-file3.mp4
        
                                 
        pn1866-file5.mp4
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      This approach enables changing the environment as easily as geometry can be changed in  virtual reality, while allowing users to view and interact with the actual physical world as they would in augmented reality. We characterize a taxonomy of  manipulations that are possible with Remixed Reality: spatial changes such as erasing objects; appearance changes such as changing textures; temporal changes such as pausing time; and viewpoint changes that allow users to see the world from different points without changing their physical location.

      Outstanding: A Perspective-Switching Technique for Covering Large Distances in VR Games

      Room-scale virtual reality games allow players to experience an unmatched level of
                  presence. A major reason is the natural navigation provided by physical walking. However,
                  the tracking space is still limited, and viable alternatives or extensions are ...

      Abstract
      Room-scale  virtual reality games allow players to experience an unmatched level of presence. A major reason is the natural navigation provided by physical walking. However, the tracking space is still limited, and viable alternatives or extensions are required to reach further  virtual destinations.

      SpaceTokens: Interactive Map Widgets for Location-centric Interactions
      
            
        
               
      • Daniel Miau, 
        • 
               
      • Steven Feiner
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '18: Proceedings of the 2018 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsApril 2018, Paper No.: 248, pp 112https://doi.org/10.1145/3173574.3173822
      
            
      
               		
               
      Map users often need to interact repetitively with multiple important locations. For
                  example, a traveler may frequently check her hotel or a train station on a map, use
                  them to localize an unknown location, or investigate routes involving them. ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 1
          • 
                                 
        • 263
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics
        
                                 
        Total Citations1
        
                                 
        Total Downloads263
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months65

          • 
                              
        
                              
        Supplementary Material
        
                                 
        pn2537-file3.mp4
        
                                 
        
                                 
        pn2537-file5.mp4
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      We propose SpaceTokens, interactive widgets that act as clones of locations, and which users can create and place on map edges like  virtual whiteboard magnets.
      They empower users to rapidly perform location-centric tasks directly using locations: users can  select combinations of on-screen locations and SpaceTokens to control the map window, or connect them to create routes.

      Abstract

      Virtual projection: exploring optical projection as a metaphor for multi-device interaction
      
            
        
               
      • Dominikus Baur, 
        • 
               
      • Sebastian Boring, 
        • 
               
      • Steven Feiner
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '12: Proceedings of the SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2012, pp 16931702https://doi.org/10.1145/2207676.2208297
      
            
      
               		
               
      Handheld optical projectors provide a simple way to overcome the limited screen real-estate
                  on mobile devices. We present virtual projection (VP), an interaction metaphor inspired
                  by how we intuitively control the position, size, and orientation of a ...
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 37
          • 
                                 
        • 1,537
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics
        
                                 
        Total Citations37
        
                                 
        Total Downloads1,537
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months96
        
                                 
        Last 6 weeks21
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 1
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Supplementary Material
        
                                 
        paperfile1280-3.mp4
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      We present  virtual projection (VP), an interaction metaphor inspired by how we intuitively control the position, size, and orientation of a handheld optical projector's image. VP is based on tracking a handheld device without an optical projector and allows  selecting a target display on which to position, scale, and orient an item in a single gesture.
      VP also supports dynamic filtering based on the projection frustum, creating overview and detail applications, and  selecting portions of a larger display for zooming and panning.

      WireFab: Mix-Dimensional Modeling and Fabrication for 3D Mesh Models
      
            
        
               
      • Min Liu, 
        • 
               
      • Yunbo Zhang, 
        • 
               
      • Jing Bai, 
        • 
               
      • Yuanzhi Cao, 
        • 
               
      • Jeffrey M. Alperovich, 
        • 
               
      • Karthik Ramani
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '17: Proceedings of the 2017 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsMay 2017, pp 965976https://doi.org/10.1145/3025453.3025619
      
            
      
               		
               
      Many rapid fabrication technologies are directed towards layer wise printing or laser
                  based prototyping. We propose WireFab, a rapid modeling and prototyping system that
                  uses bent metal wires as the structure framework. WireFab approximates both the ...
               
      
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 4
          • 
                                 
        • 409
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Metrics
        
                                 
        Total Citations4
        
                                 
        Total Downloads409
        
                                 
        Last 12 Months67
        
                                 
        Last 6 weeks18
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        
                              
          
                                 
        • 1
          • 
                              
        
                              
        Supplementary Material
        
                                 
        pn1799p.mp4
        
                              
        
                           
        
                        
        • 
                        
      • 
                           
        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      WireFab approximates both the skeletal articulation and the skin appearance of the corresponding  virtual skin meshes, and it allows users to personalize the designs by (1) specifying joint positions and part segmentations, (2) defining joint types and motion ranges to build a wire-based skeletal model, and (3) abstracting the segmented meshes into mixed-dimensional appearance patterns or attachments. The WireFab is designed to allow the user to choose how to best preserve the fidelity of the topological structure and articulation motion while  selectively maintaining the fidelity of the geometric appearance.

      Abstract

        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      In this paper, we investigate the feasibility of head-based text entry for HMDs, by which, the user controls a pointer on a  virtual keyboard using head rotation.
      Users of TapType  select a letter by pointing to it and tapping a button. Users of DwellType  select a letter by pointing to it and dwelling over it for a period of time.

      Virtual birding: extending an environmental pastime into the virtual world for citizen science
      
            
        
               
      • Mark Cottman-Fields, 
        • 
               
      • Margot Brereton, 
        • 
               
      • Paul Roe
        • 
            
      
            
      CHI '13: Proceedings of the SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing SystemsApril 2013, pp 20292032https://doi.org/10.1145/2470654.2466268
      
            
      
               		
               
      This paper investigates engaging experienced birders, as volunteer citizen scientists,
                  to analyze large recorded audio datasets gathered through environmental acoustic monitoring.
                  Although audio data is straightforward to gather, automated analysis ...
               
      
               
      
            
      
            
      
               
      
                  
      
                     
        
                        
      •

          •

        Highlights
        
                        
        • 
                     
      
                     
      
                        
      Abstract
      This study contributes an understanding of how  virtual interactions and practices can be developed to complement existing practices of experienced birders in the physical world.
